awd_titl_txt: CAREER: FIRE Lab Investigation of Stress-induced Sleep in C. elegans
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite the fundamental importance of sleep, the cellular function of sleep remains controversial. Sleep is recognized to be conserved across species, and in recent years sleep research has been extended to model organisms that provide powerful tools for genetic analysis. This project focuses on identification of genes and signaling pathways that control sleep behavior using the roundworm C. elegans as model organism. The principal investigator and her undergraduate students at California State University Northridge, a primarily undergraduate Hispanic-serving institution, have shown that exposure to environmental stresses can trigger sleep in C. elegans. Further, they demonstrated that stress-induced sleep is beneficial, and they have begun to identify several components of a genetic pathway that mediates this beneficial effect.  This project expands on this work and illuminates the mechanism through which epidermal growth factor signaling contributes to stress-induced sleep.  Additionally, the project uses cutting-edge molecular techniques to identify other genetic pathways critical in the regulation of stress-induced sleep. The broader impacts of this CAREER award include Full Immersion Research Experience (FIRE), a course the principal investigator redesigned with the goal of giving students an original research experience, and the integration of this lab course with the investigator's research program on sleep.

The identification of a sleep state in C. elegans that is triggered by conditions, such as noxious heat or tissue damage, suggests that perturbation of cellular homeostasis may contribute to sleep drive. Stress-induced sleep (SIS) in C. elegans may represent an ancestral state that evolved to promote recovery following environmental stress or infection. In more complex organisms, SIS may be coordinated with circadian regulation, acting to counteract perturbations of homeostasis known to be associated with prolonged wakefulness. The aim of this proposal is to characterize the genetic pathways that promote SIS. The principal investigator has shown that stress-induced sleep is dependent on Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) receptor activation within the ALA neuroendocrine cell; however, the mechanism by which stress initiates EGF signaling is not known. The first aim of this project is to investigate how and, for the purposes of sleep regulation, in which tissues cellular stress is monitored. Because EGF family ligands are produced as transmembrane precursors that must be processed for release of soluble ligand, it is likely that EGF-dependent sleep is regulated by stress-induced ectodomain shedding. The second aim of this project is to determine from which cell(s) EGF is shed in response to stress, and to characterize a candidate protease that has been identified in an RNAi screen for sleep defects. The third and final aim of this project is to identify novel components of SIS via an unbiased forward genetic screen.

por.por_cntn:
Sleep in the nematode C. elegans is unique in that it is not under circadian control, and this uncoupling of sleep from circadian rhythm facilitates the identification of drivers of sleep need. Prior to this project, our lab found that C. elegans sleeps following exposure to harmful conditions, suggesting that cellular damage is a component of sleep drive. Similar recent findings in other model organisms suggest that this cellular Stress-Induced Sleep (SIS) is a deeply conserved phenomenon. During this NSF-CAREER award we investigated the potentially conserved molecular mechanisms underlying the link between cellular damage and sleep, and integrated this research with the education and training of students from California State University Northridge, a predominantly undergraduate Hispanic-serving institution.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes 

1. One of the aims of our project was to determine whether stress-induced sleep is a direct consequence of cellular damage, or of a resulting energy deficit, or whether it is triggered simply by the sensation of noxious conditions. We showed that thermosensation is dispensable for heat stress-induced sleep, that osmosensation is dispensable for salt stress-induced sleep, and that wounding is also a sleep trigger, together indicating that SIS does not depend on the sensation of noxious environments (Goetting et al., 2020). We presented evidence that genetic variation in cellular repair pathways impacts sleep amount, and that SIS involves systemic monitoring of cellular damage. We also found that the major sensor of energy deficit, AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), is not required for SIS, suggesting that low energy is not the primary sleep trigger. Together these findings indicate that cellular damage may be a core component of sleep pressure, and that sleep in turn promotes cellular repair.

2. While sleep is inarguably beneficial, it is antagonistic to critical functions such as foraging and escape, and during this project we identified mechanisms governing behavioral plasticity in sleep drive. We showed that a well-characterized escape behavior, avoidance of high oxygen, can potently suppress the locomotor quiescence normally associated with C. elegans sleep, providing an opportunity for escape (i.e., sleepwalking out of danger). This opportunity is limited however, as our data suggests that sleep pressure continues to build during this period of sleep suppression (Soto et al., 2019). Similarly, we found that the need to forage can override SIS (Goetting et al., 2018). Interestingly, we found that prolonged food deprivation not only suppresses sleep behavior but also suppresses sleep need, with starvation protecting against the lethality associated with SIS impairments. Our data provide insight into sleep drive in C. elegans and its coordination with competing behavioral drives.

3. We previously found that stress-induced sleep depends on activation of Epidermal Growth Factor Receptors (EGFR) in the sleep-promoting ALA neuron, but the events linking cellular damage to EGFR activation were unclear. During this award, unbiased genetic screens for sleepless mutants have identified several novel sleep genes, including components acting upstream of EGFR activation. These genetic studies reveal a previously unknown EGFR ligand that is likely to be subject to stress-responsive ectodomain shedding, potentially demystifying the initiation of stress-induced sleep.

4. This project has provided preliminary data on the impact of CURE implementation on biology majors at a Hispanic-serving institution, in the form of student survey responses and metrics of student participation in post-course research and conference opportunities.

Broader Impact Outcomes

1. This NSF-CAREER project effectively integrated high-impact sleep research with the education and professional development of students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science. This award allowed the incorporation of the PIs research program into a course-based undergraduate research experience, BIOL447/L:FIRE (Full Immersion Research Experience). The five offerings of FIRE lab provided training for 74 undergraduates in molecular-genetic techniques, experimental design, data analysis, scientific literacy, and scientific communication. The project provided support for 18 undergraduates to continue their projects after the course, and allowed the PI to devote time to training, mentoring, and assistance with applications to post-graduate programs and STEM industry positions. Of the 18 students who pursued post-FIRE research, 17 entered STEM or health-related academic/career paths. These outcomes are consistent with previous studies pointing to a positive impact of undergraduate research experiences on retention in STEM.

2. While C. elegans stress-induced sleep is not under circadian control, it does share molecular conservation with vertebrate sleep. We reason that the accrual of sleep debt in vertebrates may be partially attributable to cellular damage incurred in the waking state, a notion that has gained recent support from sleep studies in zebrafish larvae. Our work in C. elegans is likely to have broad impact on our understanding of the molecular nature of sleep pressure as well as its coordination with competing drives.

For specific questions about this project and/or the information included in this NSF Project Outcomes Report, please contact Dr. Cheryl Van Buskirk at cheryl.vanbuskirk@csun.edu
